accomplishments:
Submitted first outcome in prod: 
On Nimbus I helped submit our first outcome in prod. There was a lot of challenges and learnings from that. Mostly coming back to the fact that we should always be working toward an outcome in prod. The stories we work on should have a clear path on how they relate to an outcome. Now on my second team at Rise8, I have a better understanding on the end to end process of what is required to put an outcome in prod. 




Leveraging AI:
My usage of generative code AI has skyrocketed this year alone. From maybe 5% to 85%+ of the time. Its helped me gain context on unknown topics or technologies without having to know the intricacies. I can focus on the more important aspects, such as building test or delivering quickly to gain faster iteration cycles. Using AI has helped me think at a higher level all the time, making sure the work I am doing is directly impacting users of my products/services. At the same time, I was able to jump right into platform work and make a contribution to the team without much technical background in the area. 




Closing down Nimbus:
Although Nimbus/SLD45 weather app did not continue, I learned how to leave our users in a safe place. What I mean is that our application will still provide its users value, despite not having active development/support. Even though theres not an active Rise8 team working on Nimbus, the project is in a state to picked up and immediately have tracks of work that would add more user value. It was a good learning experience, on knowing when/how to make decisions on certain features. And how not to leave production applications in an incomplete state.
enps_comments:
**Kenny Slater:**
Bryce is a great teammate to work with, I'd gladly have him on my team again. He quietly works hard and doesn't seek recognition for his hard work.

**Tiyyiba Zahid:**
I would enthusiastically rehire Bryce because he consistently demonstrate reliability, professionalism, and a strong commitment to team goals. Even without working directly together, his engagement in meetings and visible progress on deliverables reflect someone who takes ownership and adds steady value to the team’s success.

**Dan Sanker:**
Bryce consistently delivers both value and insight on the stories and features he works on. He's a great teammate to pair with, thanks to his positive attitude and his personal drive to deliver a high-quality product. He's confident in his abilities while also presenting as ready and eager to learn more, which is a fantastic combination.

**Chris Johns:**
Bryce has consistently been a highly productive engineer who has delivered key infrastructure components (GitLab, Terraform, Grafana, Mimir, Alloy, Vector, and Loki) while simultaneously contributing to critical ATO and compliance conversations and advocating for better engineering practices.

**Erica Chang:**
Bryce is a valuable member of the Bifrost team. He always takes ownership of the tickets/work he's on and is dependable when the product team needs to come to him for clarification. He's also proactive about picking up new work once he's done, ensuring that he continues to provide value to our eventual end users. He's also picked up work across all the various tracks of work, allowing him to gain more context on the project overall, which should allow him to continue to grow exponentially as an engineer.

**Delaney Coveno:**
Bryce keeps a steady focused pace. His calm and approachable energy make him easy to work with, and he is always wiling to lend a hand. He quickly got comfortable working in the Mission Manager space. He adapts quickly to change and can be relied on to get the job done. He is willing to take on any task and adeptly uses research as well as AI to learn what he needs.

**Jeremy Viray:**
Bryce is a deliberate, engaged engineer who approaches problems with curiosity and a constant drive to get better. He takes time to understand why decisions are made and speaks up when something doesn’t align. His attention to detail and commitment to building high-quality solutions set a strong bar for both code and collaboration. Working with Bryce is always easy, he adapts to any pairing dynamic and adds real value no matter his role. He brings enthusiasm, ownership, and a team-first mindset, and I’d gladly partner with him again.

**Clark Pain:**
Bryce has been a pleasure to work with. He's always willing to hop in wherever he's needed and doesn't shy away from a challenge. He's a true team player. I would happily work with Bryce again in the future.
start_stop_keep:
**Kenny Slater:**
Keep: Working hard and learning. I've never questioned your work ethic or what you were doing




Stop: NA




Start: Having a say in decisions. I believe you have enough experience to where your opinion matters in the decision making.

**Tiyyiba Zahid:**
**Keep:** Contributing with the same focus, consistency, and collaborative spirit. Your positive attitude and willingness to stay engaged across discussions help create a supportive team dynamic and keep everyone aligned on priorities.

**Dan Sanker:**
Start:
- Start taking the lead on larger, more complex features. Given your confidence and drive for quality, I'd love to see you start owning the technical design and execution of a feature from start to finish, including mentoring other devs who are contributing to it.
Stop:I don't have anything I'd recommend you stop. Your current approach to work—balancing confidence with a willingness to learn—is highly effective.
Keep:
- Keep that positive attitude and drive for quality; it makes you a go-to person for pairing.

**Chris Johns:**
Keep Doing:
- Keep tackling core, highly complex infrastructure and compliance challenges
- Keep advocating for process efficiency and stability within the platform
Start Doing:
- Start formalizing and anchoring the team’s knowledge base in your specialized technical domains
- Start focusing efforts on proactively stabilizing and architecting end-to-end pipeline flows
Stop Doing:
- Stop allowing dependency resolution for external blocks to linger unattended. (Applies to all of us)

**Erica Chang:**
- **Keep** looking for opportunities to lead the pair on a ticket, as this will allow you to grow as an engineer. 
- **Keep** taking ownership of the work you've done and stay accountable. 
- **Keep** using your software engineering to help influence some of the decisions we make for the platform.

**Delaney Coveno:**
- Start: Speaking up more in group settings and architectural discussions. His perspective and questions are valuable and it would help keep the team on the same page to hear his voice more often in group settings.
- Continue: Learning, getting through tasks quickly, and being comfortable to work with. Sharing responsibility with his pair.

**Jeremy Viray:**
You've definitely been taking lead on certain areas of work in our daily/weekly work cycles and showing good examples of sharing context throughout our large team, keep it up! One area for growth next year is incorporating more short-form feedback, both in requesting it and offering it proactively.

**Clark Pain:**
I recognize your flexibility and willingness to step in wherever needed. Keep up the grit and tenacity, you're adding invaluable horsepower to the engineering team. Keep broadening your skills and jumping into new challenges. Next year, I'd love to see you be more active in internal team conversations - you have a unique perspective that I think the team would benefit from hearing more often.
